document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic review of Polynema (Hymenoptera: Mymaridae) in Australia and New Zealand, with descriptions of eight new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic review of Polynema (Hymenoptera: Mymaridae) in Australia and New Zealand, with descriptions of eight new species

heading.emphasis:
Polynema ( Polynema ) koroleva Triapitsyn
, sp. n.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Polynema
sp.:
Noyes & Valentine 1989: 46
(mentioned as an unusual species with extremely long hairs on fore wing disc), 86 (illustrations: figs 136, 138, 139).

500 m

, J. C. Watt , Malaise Trap E1123 ENTOMOLOGY DIVISION D.Z.I. R . NZ”; 2. “ ♀
Polynema
17 Dec 1980
”. The type locality is on South Island.

Measurements of the holotype (µm). Mesosoma: 221; gaster: 288; ovipositor: 273. Scape: 100; pedicel: 55; F1: 27; F2: 48; F3: 30; F4: 26; F5: 30; F6: 42; clava: 118. Fore wing: 625:115; longest marginal seta: 227. Hind wing: 179:9; longest marginal seta: 9.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 104–106.
Polynema ( Polynema ) koroleva
, female: 104, holotype slide; 105, head in frontal view (paratype, Franz Josef Glacier, Westland Tai Poutini National Park, South Island, New Zealand); 106, habitus in dorsolateral view (paratype, Dart Hut, South Island, New Zealand).

FIGURES 107–111.
Polynema ( Polynema ) koroleva
, female: 107, antenna (holotype); 108, mesosoma (holotype); 109, mesosoma and metasoma (holotype); 110, fore wing (paratype, Moke Lake, South Island, New Zealand); 111, hind wing (paratype, Moke Lake).

FIGURES 112–116.
Polynema ( Polynema ) koroleva
, male (paratypes): 112, habitus in dorsolateral view (St. Arnaud, South Island, New Zealand); 113, antenna (Blue Cliffs, Invercargill, South Island, New Zealand); 114, fore wing (Blue Cliffs); 115, hind wing (Watts Rock, South Island, New Zealand); 116, genitalia (Blue Cliffs).

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. This brachypterous species is characterized by the unique combination of fore wing with very long discal hairlike setae ( Figs 110 , 114 ) and hind wing strongly reduced, almost without membrane in both sexes ( Figs 111 , 115 ).
Etymology. The species name is a noun in apposition; it means queen in Russian.
